Subject: Crossover Operator, Bucklands Windows NEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=162209378; y=uBaP1ri-5tzLDIN3ecin_jLgemkHiFTOhHfgI4T-zmIbwR0dvw

As best as I can determine, the Crossover operator in Buckland's Windows NE=
AT does not function quite like that described in Stanley's "Efficient Evol=
ution of Neural Networks through Complexification" report.  

I created two=
 parent genomes like those in Figure 3.3.  Buckland's code does not allow "=
each disjoint and excess gene" to be "inherited from either parent randomly=
" even when they have equal fitnesses. For equal fitnesses it can only inhe=
rit them from the shorter genome (Parent 1) otherwise it will inherit only =
from the fitter genome.  Thus one could never get the child pictured in Fig=
ure 3.3.

Has anyone made a similar conclusion or have I perhaps coded Buck=
land's program incorrectly.  I am making a version of NEAT in Labview using=
 Buckland's code and conventions as a guide. 

Also, why is the Crossover o=
nly applied to members within the same species?  Doesn't the speciation pro=
cess tend to group members with the same topology?  Would cross-species cro=
ssovers allow for new hybrids to arise?
